fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Research Unix refers to AT&T Bell Labs' software developed by the Computing Sciences Research Center. When referring to Unix before (and including) Version 7 (i.e., any Unix code base before Unix System III, c.1982), people refer to it as Ancient Unix
The BSD operating system was based on Research Unix. BSD fractured around version 4.4 into FreeBSD, NetBSD, OpenBSD.
DEC's Ultrix derives initially from Research Unix (and later BSD) for their VAX systems.

Commercial Unix served as the basis for a number of Unix-like systems. Unix Sys-V (pronounced "System Five") was the successor to 1982's UNIX System III. Sys-V underpins HP's HP-UX, Sun's Solaris (i.e., after SunOS 4.1.4), IBM's AIX, SGI's Irix.

GNU (founded September 27, 1983) started as a free alternative to Unix. They envisioned using a microkernel instead of a monolithic kernel, but have run into bad luck since starting. GNU Hurd (the name of their operating system) is jokingly expected to be released "any week now", and has been for the past 42 years.
Minix began as a microkernel for educational purposes.
Linux, inspired by Minix and GNU, began as perhaps the first open-source project with volunteers using the internet to coordinate implementation efforts.
In 1988, the POSIX standard was conceived to wrangle with this cambrian explosion of Unixes (Unices?).
The Unix operating system refers to a specific piece of software. We usually speak of "Unix-like" operating systems, a class of software inspired by "the" Unix.

Unix-like operating systems consist of at least two subsystems (process management and the file system). The philosophy underlying Unix is "Everything is a file", often compared to Objected Oriented programming's "Everything is an object".
